http://www.parabolicarc.com/2011/02/10/isro-sband-scandal-grows ISRO S-Band Scandal 

There seems to be great surprise that such a scandal is taking place at the widely respected ISRO, which is a symbol of India’s high-tech prowess and global rise. The space agency’s achievements in space are a source of great national pride.

The 2005 deal between Devas Multimedia and ISRO’s commercial arm, Antrix, involves the space agency building two S-band satellites, GSAT 6 and GSAT 6A, and the company leasing 90 percent of capacity getting use of them to deliver Internet services. ISRO did not actually allocate S-band spectrum to the company, but provided capacity on the satellites to use the spectrum. The scarce S-band spectrum was provided to deal was made with Devas with no competitive bidding. Devas includes two former high-ranking ISRO officials.

Critics have attacked the no-bid deal as having cost the government millions of dollars while benefiting a well-connected company.

The space agency is not particularly open or candid about its taxpayer-funded work. During the Chandrayaan-1 mission, ISRO went to great lengths to downplay problems with the lunar probe. For example, the agency doubled the spacecraft’s orbit claiming that all work at the lower altitude had been completed. This was false; the real reason was a major system failure that made the spacecraft difficult to control at its original altitude. This news didn’t become public until two months later.  — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Shikhar D Gupta|Shikhar D Gupta]] ([[User talk:Shikhar D Gupta|talk]] •

{{edit semi-protected|Indian Space Research Organisation|answered=no}}
"Change 

Budget
₹12,473.26 crore (US$1.8 billion) (2019–20 est.)

to 

Budget
₹10,252 crore (US$1.425 billion) (2019–20 est.)"

The ISRO's budget for 2019-2020 is 10,252 Crores,{{cite web |last1=Chaitanya |first1=SV Krishna |title=ISRO budget crosses Rs 10,252 crore with large chunk for space tech |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/business/union-budget/2019/feb/02/isro-budget-crosses-rs-10252-crore-with-large-chunk-for-space-tech-1933181.html |website=The New Indian Express |accessdate=2 February 2019}}{{cite web |title=Budget 2019: ISRO open for business, new commercial arm to harness economic benefits of ISRO |url=https://m.economictimes.com/news/science/budget-2019-isro-open-for-business-new-commercial-arm-to-harness-economic-benefits-of-isro/articleshow/70085844.cms |website=The Economic Times |accessdate=5 July 2019}} not 12,473.26 Crores as cited in the page. 

As the citation shows, the 12,473.26 Crores number was only a demand from the Department of Space, NOT the government's final approval. Moreover, the current citation mentions the budget for Department of Space as a whole and ISRO is one branch of the department only. Thus, we cannot equate the department's budget with ISRO's budget.
I propose a new article for the planned Exoworlds mission by ISRO.
I would love to do it, but since last month I have found no information about it, except that it would "explore outside the solar system".

It has been allocated a token sum in recent budget but no further details.{{cite web |title=Detailed Demands for Grants of DoS for 2019-20 |url=https://www.isro.gov.in/sites/default/files/article-files/right-to-information/detailed_demands_for_grants_of_dos_for_2019-20.pdf |accessdate=22 August 2019}}

The ISRO's budget for 2019-2020 is 10,252 Crores,{{cite web |last1=Chaitanya |first1=SV Krishna |title=ISRO budget crosses Rs 10,252 crore with large chunk for space tech |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/business/union-budget/2019/feb/02/isro-budget-crosses-rs-10252-crore-with-large-chunk-for-space-tech-1933181.html |website=The New Indian Express |accessdate=2 February 2019}}{{cite web |title=Budget 2019: ISRO open for business, new commercial arm to harness economic benefits of ISRO |url=https://m.economictimes.com/news/science/budget-2019-isro-open-for-business-new-commercial-arm-to-harness-economic-benefits-of-isro/articleshow/70085844.cms |website=The Economic Times |accessdate=5 July 2019}} not 12,473.26 Crores as cited in the page. 

As the citation shows, the 12,473.26 Crores number was only a demand from the Department of Space, NOT the government's final approval. Moreover, the current citation mentions the budget for Department of Space as a whole and ISRO is one branch of the department only. Thus, we cannot equate the department's budget with ISRO's budget.
{{done}}. Thank you.

It has been allocated a token sum in recent budget but no further details.{{cite web |title=Detailed Demands for Grants of DoS for 2019-20 |url=https://www.isro.gov.in/sites/default/files/article-files/right-to-information/detailed_demands_for_grants_of_dos_for_2019-20.pdf |accessdate=22 August 2019}}

comments.text: {{Agree}} That crash course on mission history seems unnecessary. We can do without those geo-locations, plus VSSC is not "spaceport" and thumba is merely a sounding rocket range. Needs explicit mention of ISRO being a civilian space program as well.

comments.section: Some lines in the paragraph above information box should be adjusted below.
comments.text:
I think some lines in the paragraph above 'information box' should be adjusted below, because it create a sense of boredom when anyone visits ISRO's page on wikipedia. There should be only some lines of information at starting of the page, then the 'information box' and after this the paragraph giving preliminary information about ISRO. So from the line containing 'INCOSPAR' till the end (above 'information box') should be adjusted below the information box. It will make page look more neat and clean and pretty informative. The readers will sense an easy through information about ISRO at starting. ~¶iyush¶ercev 07:08, 8 September 2019 (UTC)  —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Piyush00India|Piyush00India]] ([[User talk:Piyush00India#top|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Piyush00India|contribs]])
